reviewText:
So this what it feels like ? So this is what the wait for Half Life 3 feels like.

Half Life 2 Episode Two is the sequel to Episode One and begins straight away. We find ourselves in the outskirts of City 17 as the Citadel has now opened a portal to the Combines home world and it's now up to us to find a way to the rebel base and shut down the portal once and for all.

The gameplay is identical to previous titles in the Half Life 2 games.  Overall there's not much to say here as it's basically DLC to Half Life 2.

Graphics wise this game looks a tad bit better than Half Life 2 due to the range rendering, which I thought was under used in Half Life 2 Episode One. The portal coming from the citadel can be seen throughout the entire game which looks outstanding.

There is a reason this is my favorite Half Life title and that's the action sequences. This game is like a great action movie. Action scenes after action scenes after action scenes and it all ends up to one of the biggest cliffhanger endings in history of gaming. I'm not joking it actually pains me not knowing what happens next.

I also love the incredible soundtrack. It's beyond kick ♥♥♥ and is one of my favorite game soundtracks of all time.

In the end Half Life 2 Episode Two is a thrilling ride and it should be played by everyone. I'm glad I finally joined the bandwagon. Now I can join the Half Life 3 waiting community.

Final Rating:
10/10 - A must own and a must play

reviewText:
Nice told with Alyx

HALF-LIFE 2 EPISODE 2 starts immediately where Half-Life 2 Episode 1 ended. Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance must continue their fight, alongside the resistance, against the evil Combine. After the ever so slightly below par Episode 1, Episode 2 is a real return to form. Everything that was so good about HL2 is developed here and made even better. The narrative arc is strong, the dialogue well-written and witty, the voice acting accomplished and convincing, the environments spectacular and varied, and the mix between puzzle solving and combat just right. We meet several new enemies and some of the combat is pretty challenging, especially the final battle which is big on scale and mayhem and requires real strategy to complete. It’s a tough finale but well worth the effort. There’s so much to enjoy in the whole Half-Life series I can’t recommend these games enough.

5/5

Half Life 2 is a first person shooter game released in 2004. It was awarded as the Game of the Decade in the VGA Awards. The award was received by Gabe Newell, Valve founder.

The game takes place 20 years after the Black Mesa incident of Half Life ( The game that chaged it all ) . Gordon Freeman awakes from hibernation in City 17 and become part of the resistance to face the Combine Empire and attempt to defeat it. In the game Gordon meets Alyx Vance,  who is part of the resistance. The game is one of the pioneers in introducing a playmate .

Half Life 2 presents different enemies . The Headcrabs still produce that feeling of rejection when they attack. The action is breathtaking but it breaks , not like Call of Duty games where you shoot without breathing.

The narrative is implemented throughout the game, not with recording or notes , it is not necessary. The experience is brilliant. The Source engine allows good management of physics and the introduction of a new weapon. The gravity gun . The technology also allows open spaces in addition to traditional outdoor passageways and internal spaces .

The handling of the narrative and physics puzzles changed the way the FPS games developed from there into the future . It was a turning point in games history the same way it was the first Half Life .

The game was released for PC under Windows , required a 2 Ghz processor . 512 MB ​​of RAM , and a graphics card compatible with Direct X 8.1 . For the few resources sought at that time the graphical quality of the game was very good and ran very smoothly .

This is one of the must play" games if one is serious about being a Gamer

reviewText:
Half-Life 2: Episode Two continues the human resistances fight against the Combine, with you once again playing the role of Gordon Freeman. It takes place immediately following the occurrences of Episode One, and contains somewhere between 4-5 hours of quality content depending on how you play it.

Episode Two does a great job progressing the title through every aspect when compared to Episode One, just like Episode One did in comparison to the base game. With Episode Two you will find slightly updated visuals by the way of textures and lighting, various new mechanics, and a couple of new enemies and weapon types. However, the narrative is easily what develops the most, which is at the same time the most frustrating part of this installment. Great strides were made into understanding the plot, you become more invested than ever, and then BOOM! Everything is stopped in its tracks, a huge cliff hanger occurs, and nearly a decade later there is no extension to the series. I took all the self-control I had to get this far still writing a genuinely informative review, so I'm just going to let it all out now.

Personal Rating: ♥♥♥♥ YOU VALVE (10)/10

I shall live and die with the vortigaunts. I am the crowbar in the darkness. I am the researcher in the labs. I am the missile that burns against the Combine, the light that brings the end of their days, the siren that wakes the sleepers, the shield that guards the realms of men. reviewText:
Because the soundtrack is the best of the Half-Life universe and because you want to see the gnome in the rocket. Alyx's ♥♥♥ is also counting if you're a certain friend of mine.

The game is starting after the crash of your train and the destruction of City 17. You're alone with Alyx in a forest and after finding an abandoned outpost, you're attacked by an enemy you've never seen before. Alyx is badly wounded and her life is at stake, only Vortigaunts can save her. And from there, you're going to a journey in a mine. And reaching the White Forest base will take time too.

This episode was released in the Orange Box, that is including Half-Life 2, Episode 1, Portal and Team Fortress 2. It was the first Half-Life on PC to have achievements, because of the release on X-box.

While the game is short, the episode is still intense as you're meeting more Antlions (and new types too), you have to defend the outpost from them in an intense battle, a new car makes its appearance, a new combine type is also making its debut, spicing up the game but also, you're finally face to face to a real Combine. And that's scary because you can't do anything about it.

The White Forest ambush is also a good moment but the most difficult passage is White Forest defense against Striders. If they reach the base, it's game over. But with the Magnusson devices, you can quickly kill them. If you manage to make them stick, that's it.

However, while this passage is really hard for the achievement with no building destroyed, the most annoying quest (for achievement, you're not forced to do it) is to bring the gnome to the rocket. And the gnome in your car?  Well, it's falling off every 5 seconds. So, in other words, you're going forward, stop the car, get the gnome back, restart the engine, advance, stop the car, etc... And another one that can rival that is to kill every Antlion larva in the mine (333 to crush) and some of them are well hidden.

With the cliffhanger, you'll understand why it's since 8 years that we're waiting for the Episode 3. Or Half-Life 3.

Episode 2 continues on where Episode 1 left off. Gordon and Alyx have already escaped from City 17 and have to get to White Forest - a resistance base. Throughout their journey they are constantly chased by the Combine.

While in Episode 1 the setting was mostly urban, in Episode 2 you traverse through the countryside and the area around it. When you have progressed enough through the game you will find an old muscle car that you will use to get to White Forest, func_vehicle returns in Episode 2 in contrast to its absence in Episode 1. Not that much puzzles are tied to the passage of the car being blocked, though they still are present.

New enemies added include the notorious Hunters. They usually travel in packs and are tough opponents. Alyx is the first to have an experince with a Hunter and it seems that they are too strong, but they can be defeated relatively easy, depending on what you shoot them with. You will also face a lot of striders and obtain a new device used to destroy them - a Magnusson Device.

Episode 2 is made with the same engine as HL2 and Episode 1 so the graphics are the same.

In the end, if you have played the other games, but not this one, then you should buy it.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Half-Life 2: Episode Two was the last of the weird counting method Valve used to make sure they didn't need to count to three. Half-Life 2: Episode Two was developed by Valve Corporation and released late 2007.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: The story picks up, right where Half-Life 2: Episode One left off; Alyx Vance and Gordon Freeman are going to be reunited with Eli Vance and Dr. Kleiner to plan the next step in their battle against the Combine forces.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577049

Gameplay: This game returns to the more familiar setting of Half-Life 2, you aren't forced to rely solely on the Gravity gun like in most of Half-Life 2: Episode One. There is a new NPC that you encounter called “Hunters”, these are savage killing machines that are very imposing and at times down right freighting when encountered.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577103

Achievements: There are 22 achievements on Half-Life 2: Episode Two. One third of the achievements are unlocked just by playing through the story. The rest are pretty tough and require careful planning, or a very long time running around.
The most noteworthy achievements in this game are: Get Some Grub (“Squish every antlion grub in Episode Two” – That took forever.), and Little Rocket Man (requiring you to Carry a Garden Gnome from the beginning of the game to nearly the end) – I have an obsession with garden gnomes because of this achievement, stay away from the precious!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=520577080

Price: Half-Life 2: Episode Two is priced at $7.99, you're better off purchasing The Orange Box for $19.99, where you will gain all the Half-Life 2 games + Portal 1.

Conclusion: I think Half-Life 2: Episode One, and Half-Life 2: Episode Two, really should have been one amazing game. Separate they're short but sweet. To quickly recap, Story: Excellent. Gameplay: nearly identical to the previous games. Achievements: Getting 100% completed will take longer then Half-Life 2, or Episode One. Price: a bit high, but the orange box is an excellent deal for the whole series.
I recommend this game to anyone who's played Half-Life 2 and Half-Life 2: Episode One. You don't want to jump into this game, you will want to play the previous games first.
Thank you for reading my review!

reviewText:
SPOILERS AHEAD
Continuing the plot of Half-Life 2 and Episode One, Episode Two consists of seven chapters telling the story of Gordon Freeman and Alyx Vance's journey to a large Lambda Resistance base called White Forest. The Combine's Earth occupation forces have used the destruction of the Citadel to begin opening a massive super portal which, if allowed to reach critical size, would allow the Combine to call in reinforcements from their homeworld and destroy the Resistance. However, as explained by Dr. Kleiner's broadcast in Episode One, it has also caused a communications blackout, leaving the Combine isolated and disorganized in the meantime. In addition, Combine Advisors, some of them still unhatched from their pods, are scattered about the region after evacuating the Citadel. A crucial part of the plot is the Combine's message home, which was copied by Alyx and Gordon before making their escape, that the Combine sacrificed the Citadel to send. It contains data on the Combine portal code, which the Resistance can use to collapse the portal before it forms completely.

After Gordon and Alyx climb out of the wreckage of the train they used to escape City 17, they proceed away from the former city on foot. At an old transmission station, the duo temporarily establish communication with Dr. Kleiner and Eli Vance, who are currently at White Forest. After an update of events at the now-destroyed Citadel, as well discovering the importance of the transmission packet copy that Alyx had made, they are cut off as Combine sweep the area, forcing them to move. At an abandoned mine, Alyx is critically wounded by a Hunter. A vortigaunt discovers them, and leads them to an underground Resistance shelter. The vortigaunts there have the power to heal Alyx; however, Gordon must first venture into the nearby antlion colony to recover the larval extract necessary for the healing procedure.

Gordon retrieves the extract and the vortigaunts begin to heal Alyx. While they are distracted, the G-Man is able to contact Gordon for the first time since the start of Episode One. He hints at Alyx's importance to his own long-term plans, revealing that he saved Alyx's life at Black Mesa despite objections from an unspecified third party.
